Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Understanding mate choice and hybridization of the endangered red wolf
Award.AbstractNarration: Small populations face unique risks associated with inbreeding and reduced genetic variation which can influence hybridization and/or disease susceptibility reducing viability and likelihood of survival. This is especially true for endangered populations, which are vulnerable to inbreeding and loss of variation because they are small by definition and frequently consist of related individuals. This study will examine whether inbreeding and low variation at genes important for disease resistance: (1) affect reproductive success and survivorship (fitness) in endangered red wolves; (2) cause red wolves to seek unrelated or genetically dissimilar mates including mates from closely related species, and; (3) affect red wolf disease susceptibility as measured by parasite load and immune assays that test the ability of blood to fight pathogens. Preliminary results reveal that red wolves are highly inbred and have little variation at genes important for disease resistance which may cause them to experience reduced fitness, hybridize with coyotes to avoid mating with kin, and increase their susceptibility to pathogens. Results will help wild red wolf recovery by informing managers about actions needed to increase reproductive success and survival, such as increasing genetic variability through the introduction of captive red wolves, screening potential red wolf mates for genetic compatibility, and increasing vaccination regimes to reduce pathogen infections. More broadly, this study may highlight the importance of maintaining large natural populations with high levels of genetic variation and increase understanding of the factors leading to hybridization and disease in endangered species. Finally, this study will integrate research and education by taking advantage of Louisiana State University's extensive high school and undergraduate student outreach programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Wildlife diseases influence the conservation and management of biodiversity. This is especially true for endangered populations, which may be more vulnerable to disease because of inbreeding and loss of genetic variation associated with small population size. In addition to increasing disease susceptibility, inbreeding and reduced genetic variation can reduce animal survival and reproductive success (i.e. fitness). As such, understanding how inbreeding and reduced genetic variation influence fitness and disease susceptibility is of growing importance to conservation issues generally. This study examined whether inbreeding and low variation at genes important for disease resistance affected fitness or disease susceptibility in endangered red wolves. We found that red wolves were highly inbred, but fitness was not directly reduced due to inbreeding. More inbred wolves, were however, smaller than less inbred wolves, which could indirectly reduce a wolf’s ability to reproduce. Further, red wolves had relatively little variation at genes important for disease resistance, yet we found that several immune genes provided resistance to tick-borne pathogens. Red wolves may be more susceptible to pathogens because of their low immune gene variation relative to their more abundant relative, the coyote. Coyotes living in the same region as red wolves were found to carry more pathogens and could be a source of disease to endangered red wolves.

Results will help wild red wolf recovery by informing managers about the need to monitor for the deleterious effects of inbreeding such as susceptibility to coyote mediated disease outbreaks. For instance, management actions could include increasing genetic variability through the introduction of captive red wolves and potentially increasing vaccination regimes to reduce pathogen infections. More broadly, this study highlighted the importance of maintaining large natural populations with high levels of genetic variation and increase understanding of the factors leading to disease in endangered species. Finally, this study integrated research and education by taking advantage of Louisiana State University’s extensive high school and undergraduate student outreach programs, through which the co-PIs taught wildlife courses and mentored students.
